provided the implementation of foobar accessed the import manager created by importsLocation. Changes committed to CVS Fixed in build I200603161025. Move to verified as per bug 206558.

Bug.Summery: Compiler compliance level 1.4 still allows 1.5 API to go through
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse 3.2 M4 with 1.5 JRE
Did a code completion on Collections.s Got Collections.emptyList(). Which is 1.5 specific. Broke head for 1.4 users. Correct version was Collections.EMPTY_LIST
Is there a workaround? Or do you just guarantee bytecode is 1.4 but can't do anything but the java class libraries themselves?
Thanks, Chris > Did a code completion on Collections.s typo. I meant 'Did a code completion on Collections.e' If you put 1.5 classlibs on your classpath, then you get completions which maybe 1.5 specific. We are not excluding 1.5 specific constructs, simply because we don't really know what level they are.
In 1.4 target mode, we issue 1.4 classfiles, which are guaranteed to use any 1.5 constructs in their sources, but if you compiled them against 1.5 libs, then you might have 1.5 binary dependencies from thereon.
So though you produced 1.4 classfiles, they will need a 1.5 JRE to be executed, due to the dependencies you did introduce.
Best for 1.4 compliance to use 1.4 libs on your classpath, unless you like to live dangerously.
Closing as invalid. I think this is a serious usability problem. I just did the same thing and almost borke a nightly build, if Kevin had not stayed late that night and caught it we would have been broken for several days (Cheers Kev).
org.eclipse.ui.ide has it's compiler compliance set to 1.4. I am using a 1.6 VM. I accidentally used some 1.6 API and released it to the ide plug-in.
We should at least have a warning marker generated that I am using API that is not compatible with the compliance level of our code - there is no way a user is going to figure this out on their own. Probably would require a custom JRE version checking tool that knows about the official public API's and their JRE requirement. That's some work...
You might start by properly settings your installed JRE. You installed a JRE1.4 and you set it as an exact match. It should be picked up as the JRE of your project. Darin - can't execution environment help us here ? I would expect some access rules to kick in in such a scenario ? The access rules for execution environments only go to the class level - not methods within classes. If access rules supported finer granularity, we could potentially expand the rules. Would it make sense to introduce a stricter mode for the compiler where the compiler tests that the classfile compatibility of the used JARs is not higher than the configured source/classfile compliance? Genereate an error: 'Trying to compiler 1.4 source against a 1.5 library'. There would be a problem then in mixing plug-ins. For instance I am using Eclipse but developing another plug-in with 1.5 compliance so I would get errors if there were a mix of compliance levels in my setup.
However an error that flags me using an API with a higher than specified compliance level would be ideal. Re: comment 8 There is already a build preferences for checking incompatible required libraries. Re: comment 9 Once API tooling defines a set of rules, we should leverage these as (finer-grain) access rules, or something along these lines; for JDT users to see leveraged as they code. Given option already exist as per comment 10, and API tooling is around the corner to go after such issues, I don't think we should invest more in compiler support.
Right now, the real answer is to make sure to have the proper level of libs on your classpath (and to detect inconsistencies, enable the option mentioned in comment 10).
No further action planned. Is that ok? Philippe when you say have the proper level of libs on your classpath do you mean only use Foundation libs? No good for us as we have a mix of compiler levels.
If you have something better on the way I agree we should just wait for this but I am not sure how to easily set up your solution so that we don't continually have this problem. I personally have installed several JREs on my machine. Foundation 1.0, Java4, Java5 and Java6 (amongst others). Given this, with required execution environments properly set on my projects, each of them is picking the right flavor at compile time (through JREContainer resolution).
This guarantees that each project is compiled against the right library.
As you observed indeed, there is no one JRE to rule them all... Would it make sense to set the 'incompatible required libraries' to 'warning' by default? I would be happy to set to error myself - this is what we would do in our project preferences. But warning is a good start I wouldn't change its default, because of the lib packaging issue (not us, but libs causing grief).
Java4 means target 1.2 in 1.3 source mode. However, some of the standard libs are stamped as 1.4, hence from the compiler standpoint it looks like these are incompatible with the fact you want to deliver code to a 1.2 target...
Ideally, the JRE container should rule these libs out of the classpath, to ensure that you do not accidentally code against them and really mean to deliver code for 1.2 targets. In reality, not many people do code for target prior to 1.4, so the glitch is tolerable, but still the warning would be kind of proeminent. Verified for 3.4M4

I meant 'Did a code completion on Collections.e' If you put 1.5 classlibs on your classpath, then you get completions which maybe 1.5 specific. We are not excluding 1.5 specific constructs, simply because we don't really know what level they are.
In 1.4 target mode, we issue 1.4 classfiles, which are guaranteed to use any 1.5 constructs in their sources, but if you compiled them against 1.5 libs, then you might have 1.5 binary dependencies from thereon.
So though you produced 1.4 classfiles, they will need a 1.5 JRE to be executed, due to the dependencies you did introduce.
Best for 1.4 compliance to use 1.4 libs on your classpath, unless you like to live dangerously.
Closing as invalid. I think this is a serious usability problem. I just did the same thing and almost borke a nightly build, if Kevin had not stayed late that night and caught it we would have been broken for several days (Cheers Kev).
org.eclipse.ui.ide has it's compiler compliance set to 1.4. I am using a 1.6 VM. I accidentally used some 1.6 API and released it to the ide plug-in.
We should at least have a warning marker generated that I am using API that is not compatible with the compliance level of our code - there is no way a user is going to figure this out on their own. Probably would require a custom JRE version checking tool that knows about the official public API's and their JRE requirement. That's some work...
You might start by properly settings your installed JRE. You installed a JRE1.4 and you set it as an exact match. It should be picked up as the JRE of your project. Darin - can't execution environment help us here ? I would expect some access rules to kick in in such a scenario ? The access rules for execution environments only go to the class level - not methods within classes. If access rules supported finer granularity, we could potentially expand the rules. Would it make sense to introduce a stricter mode for the compiler where the compiler tests that the classfile compatibility of the used JARs is not higher than the configured source/classfile compliance? Genereate an error: 'Trying to compiler 1.4 source against a 1.5 library'. There would be a problem then in mixing plug-ins. For instance I am using Eclipse but developing another plug-in with 1.5 compliance so I would get errors if there were a mix of compliance levels in my setup.
However an error that flags me using an API with a higher than specified compliance level would be ideal. Re: comment 8 There is already a build preferences for checking incompatible required libraries. Re: comment 9 Once API tooling defines a set of rules, we should leverage these as (finer-grain) access rules, or something along these lines; for JDT users to see leveraged as they code. Given option already exist as per comment 10, and API tooling is around the corner to go after such issues, I don't think we should invest more in compiler support.
Right now, the real answer is to make sure to have the proper level of libs on your classpath (and to detect inconsistencies, enable the option mentioned in comment 10).
No further action planned. Is that ok? Philippe when you say have the proper level of libs on your classpath do you mean only use Foundation libs? No good for us as we have a mix of compiler levels.
If you have something better on the way I agree we should just wait for this but I am not sure how to easily set up your solution so that we don't continually have this problem. I personally have installed several JREs on my machine. Foundation 1.0, Java4, Java5 and Java6 (amongst others). Given this, with required execution environments properly set on my projects, each of them is picking the right flavor at compile time (through JREContainer resolution).
This guarantees that each project is compiled against the right library.
As you observed indeed, there is no one JRE to rule them all... Would it make sense to set the 'incompatible required libraries' to 'warning' by default? I would be happy to set to error myself - this is what we would do in our project preferences. But warning is a good start I wouldn't change its default, because of the lib packaging issue (not us, but libs causing grief).
Java4 means target 1.2 in 1.3 source mode. However, some of the standard libs are stamped as 1.4, hence from the compiler standpoint it looks like these are incompatible with the fact you want to deliver code to a 1.2 target...
Ideally, the JRE container should rule these libs out of the classpath, to ensure that you do not accidentally code against them and really mean to deliver code for 1.2 targets. In reality, not many people do code for target prior to 1.4, so the glitch is tolerable, but still the warning would be kind of proeminent. Verified for 3.4M4

Bug.Summery: Test Log Viewer: easy information retrieval from large logs
Bug.WithStack:
Test logs usually contain very large number of events. Each event has its own details information. Naturally, there need to be some ways to get to the information that's interesting to the user. Navigation, searching, filtering are all different ways to achieve this.
This task is a little more challenging to TPTP as a framework. There are some basic types of execution events from TPTP. Consuming tools can have their own types of event by extending ExecutionEvent. For each type of event, different tool can generate different types of details information and thus furture customize them. This requires the way(s) to retrieve information also be extensible. So that it can be tuned by different tools.
Lastly, the callenge lies in design for user experience. To allow users to get to the information they want, and at the same time, KISS. (Keep It Simple & Stupid) Reassign to Bianca. Updating target to future as requested by the PMC.
Enhancements are targeted to future if not in plan for the current release. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As such, TPTP is not delivering enhancements. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement is resolved as WONTFIX. Bug.Summery: Eclipse will not start on Intel-based macs
Bug.WithStack:
I am trying to run Eclipse 3.1.2 on a MacBook Pro (Dual Core 2.0) and Os X 10.4.5. When starting Eclipse, it immediatly crashes with an error: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /Applications/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/63/1/.cp/libswt-pi-carbon-3139.jnilib
I will try to attach the entire .log file. Created attachment 36076 Logfile produced when eclipse crashes
This log contains the error and full stack trace. Eclipse 3.1.2 pre-dated the existence of the mactel machines. Therefore this is normal. Now the question is do we want to rebuid 3.1.2 for mactel? If we build, what does it means to other plug-ins from the foundation? I think that would be a very good idea. Even when 3.2 ships there will be large sections of our user base that will continue to use 3.1 for dependency reasons alone. (In reply to comment #3) > If we build, what does it means to other plug-ins from the foundation? >
For one thing ... if you are talking about a "3.1.3" then we in WTP would like to "line up" with that date. (And if you do have a 3.1.3, there might be a few other candidates .. like the problem on 3.1 stream using underscores in qualifier names.
But, if you are just talking about a new fragemnnt .. a 3.1.2B .. then we in WTP would not even re-test. Here I would like to keep the focus on rebuilding the existing pieces that needs to be (mostly people with native source code), see if this is possible for the actors concerned, and don't want to mix that up with 3.1.x builds.
moving to SWT since they would be the main players here. If there is a 3.1.x, then we could consider building the libraries. No action for now. *** Bug 139726 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991 Closing as won't fix. All new releases of eclipse run well on intel macs.

Bug.Summery: improve synchronization performance and job queuing

Bug.Summery: [Progress] Truncation in progress indicator is too aggressive
Bug.WithStack:
3.2 M5
Noticed that the label in the progress indicator was truncated (with "..." in the middle), but there was still quite a bit of available space to the right. Created attachment 36081 Screen shot Also, notice the vertical line between the trim drag handle and the text. Is that a legacy separator that can be removed?
I recommend just using a CLabel, which uses an ellipsis in the middle, rather than doing our own truncation.
For consistency with view and editor tabs, we should probably truncate at the end instead (although CLabel currently only truncates in the middle). I find truncation in the middle to be highly unreadable. That's really a separate issue than the wasted space though.
This was fixed up in 3.3.

Bug.Summery: Simplified Chinese characters not displayed under Japanese

Lines.Line: 1. Log into HP under S-Ch-UTF8.
2. Open HP system editor and create a few text files with S-CH contents and names.
3. Log out of HP and log back in under Ja-UTF8.
4. In HP terminal, go to the folder where the S-CH files are stored.Type "ls -la" in terminal.
Result:
See a lot of white-spaces in file names.
5. Open these files in HP system editor, see the same behavior as described in step 4.

Bug.WithStack:
I would like to get an answer from the Eclipse team whether this is a Eclipse bug or a HP restriction.
The client of our product is RCP. We have a test case to access Simplified Chinese(Unicode) database from a Japanese(UTF-8) client. We found that if we log into HP under Japanese UTF-8, and then access Chinese Unicode characters from our RCP client, a lot of the Chinese Unicode characters are displayed as white-spaces. In the mean time, we also got messages printed out on the HP terminal "Unicode '<character unicode>' not found in table databases".
I did some other investigation on HP: 1. Log into HP under S-Ch-UTF8. 2. Open HP system editor and create a few text files with S-CH contents and names. 3. Log out of HP and log back in under Ja-UTF8. 4. In HP terminal, go to the folder where the S-CH files are stored.Type "ls -la" in terminal. Result: See a lot of white-spaces in file names. 5. Open these files in HP system editor, see the same behavior as described in step 4.
Is this something that can be fixed by Eclipse? If this is a HP restriction, I would like to get some verification from the Eclipse team so we can add it to our release notes. When you log in a specific locale the system set its font (application font, sytem font, terminal font, etc) to something that support the characters of that locale.
The font used by HP when you log in sch does not support japanese. The application can try to fix this by setting a japanese font in the editor if it knows the content is in japanese. Some platforms have font linking (or font fallback) to fix this kind of problem. Motif is not the case, you need to set the right font in the widget,if the default chinese font doesn't support japanese there is nothing I can do to help.
Closing.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I would like to get an answer from the Eclipse team whether this is a Eclipse bug or a HP restriction.
The client of our product is RCP. We have a test case to access Simplified Chinese(Unicode) database from a Japanese(UTF-8) client. We found that if we log into HP under Japanese UTF-8, and then access Chinese Unicode characters from our RCP client, a lot of the Chinese Unicode characters are displayed as white-spaces. In the mean time, we also got messages printed out on the HP terminal "Unicode '<character unicode>' not found in table databases".
I did some other investigation on HP: 1. Log into HP under S-Ch-UTF8. 2. Open HP system editor and create a few text files with S-CH contents and names. 3. Log out of HP and log back in under Ja-UTF8. 4. In HP terminal, go to the folder where the S-CH files are stored.Type "ls -la" in terminal. Result: See a lot of white-spaces in file names. 5. Open these files in HP system editor, see the same behavior as described in step 4.
Is this something that can be fixed by Eclipse? If this is a HP restriction, I would like to get some verification from the Eclipse team so we can add it to our release notes. When you log in a specific locale the system set its font (application font, sytem font, terminal font, etc) to something that support the characters of that locale.
The font used by HP when you log in sch does not support japanese. The application can try to fix this by setting a japanese font in the editor if it knows the content is in japanese. Some platforms have font linking (or font fallback) to fix this kind of problem. Motif is not the case, you need to set the right font in the widget,if the default chinese font doesn't support japanese there is nothing I can do to help.
Closing.

Bug.Summery: Why does the GMF cross-referencer ignore unchangeable features?
Bug.WithStack:
The GMF CrossReferenceAdapter class deliberately ignores features that are not derived but also not changeable. This does not seem to make sense, as the separation of isDerived from isChangeable suggests that a feature may be unchangeable but also not derived.
Ignoring derived references perhaps makes sense, because derived references are expected to be redundant with some other non-derived reference. However, the same does not hold for unchangeable references. The filter to not include unchangeable features has been removed. The filter to remove container and containment references also has been removed. The container and containment references filter was moved into the MSLCrossReferenceAdapter in the comptability plugin. The filter behaviour of CrossReferenceAdapter is consistent with the ECrossReferenceAdapter [target cleanup] 1.0 M6 was the original target milestone for this bug [GMF Restructure] Bug 319140 : product GMF and component Runtime EMF was the original product and component for this bug
Bug.WithOutStack:
The GMF CrossReferenceAdapter class deliberately ignores features that are not derived but also not changeable. This does not seem to make sense, as the separation of isDerived from isChangeable suggests that a feature may be unchangeable but also not derived.
Ignoring derived references perhaps makes sense, because derived references are expected to be redundant with some other non-derived reference. However, the same does not hold for unchangeable references. The filter to not include unchangeable features has been removed. The filter to remove container and containment references also has been removed. The container and containment references filter was moved into the MSLCrossReferenceAdapter in the comptability plugin. The filter behaviour of CrossReferenceAdapter is consistent with the ECrossReferenceAdapter [target cleanup] 1.0 M6 was the original target milestone for this bug [GMF Restructure] Bug 319140 : product GMF and component Runtime EMF was the original product and component for this bug

Bug.Summery: [editor] Do not allow XSD files to be imported in wsdl:import statements when WS-I compliance is set to suggest or require
Bug.WithStack: The WSDL editor allows a user to import another document using the wsdl:import element. In the graphical view, right click on Imports and select Add Import. You are given the option of importing both WSDL and XSD files through the wsdl:import element. The WS-I basic profile disallows importing XSD files with wsdl:import elements. When WS-I compliance is set to suggest this wizard should show a warning when a user selects to import an XSD file. When WS-I compliance is set to require this wizard should not allow a user to import an XSD file. Thank you Lawrence, this sounds more like an enhancement.

Bug.Summery: [Progress] IllegalArgumentException in ProgressInfoItem.refresh()
Bug.WithStack:
While running some of the import tests (specifically, the ImportExistingTest class) I get the an illegal arg exception which appears to be a result of code in the ProgressInfoItem.refresh() method: taskEntries = taskEntries.subList(0, infos.length-1);
In my case, infos is an empty array so subList is called with (0, -1) which throws an IllegalArgumentException.

Bug.Summery: [Markers] Problems view doing a bundle lookup everytime it populates a table enty
Bug.WithStack:
20060307
Whenever we populate a table entry we do a getIDEImageDescritpr with a path which causes us to hit the bundle code to do a lookup. The 3 icons in the problems view should be defined in workbench images so this happens once. Fixing this reduces image lookup time on 100 items from 270ms to 5 ms Fixed in build >20060313. Images moved to IDEWorkbenchImages Verified in 20060328
Bug.WithOutStack:
20060307
